docs.lead_paragraph: Few mothers need persuading when it comes to hugging their newborns, but a new study suggests that encouraging them to do so can help reduce babies' pain during a standard medical test.

headline.main: When a Hug Helps Relieve the Pain

docs.abstract: New study finds that a mother giving her newborn a hug during blood-test on newborn's heel will reduce baby's pain (S)
docs.snippet: Few mothers need persuading when it comes to hugging their newborns, but a new study suggests that encouraging them to do so can help reduce babies' pain during a standard medical test.

docs.lead_paragraph: The phenomenon can be frightening and is more common than most doctors believe. A person smells or tastes something funny and soon complains of feeling ill. Minutes later, witnesses also feel strange. The outbreak spreads like a chain reaction. Many go to a hospital. But after physical examinations and dozens of blood tests, nothing significant shows up. Health officials are summoned but find no cause. A few days later, relapses and possibly a new wave of attacks may occur. When the all-clear is given, the diagnosis is mass hysteria, also known as epidemic hysteria, mass psychogenic illness and mass sociogenic illness.

headline.main: Mysterious Illnesses Often Turn Out to Be Mass Hysteria

docs.abstract: Lawrence K Altman column on mysterious illnesses that turn out to be the result of mass hysteria; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The phenomenon can be frightening and is more common than most doctors believe.    A person smells or tastes something funny and soon complains of feeling ill. Minutes later, witnesses also feel strange. The outbreak spreads like a chain reaction....

docs.lead_paragraph: A recent study of women on active duty in the Army found that some 8 percent had eating disorders like bulimia or anorexia. That's not as high as the rate some studies have found among female athletes, but higher than that found among women in general, where the rate is about 1 percent to 3 percent.

headline.main: Trouble for Women in the Mess Hall

docs.abstract: Recent study of women on active duty in the Army finds that some 8 percent have eating disorders like bulimia or anorexia (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnant women who show signs that their fetuses may have anemia, which in serious cases can require treatment even before the baby is born, have traditionally been advised to go undergo diagnostic procedures that involve physically piercing their wombs. The tests are effective at confirming the disease but can cause their own risk to the mother or fetus.

headline.main: A Safer, Simpler Way to Test a Fetus

docs.abstract: New study finds that Doppler ultrasound may be simpler, safer and less expensive way to diagnose fetal anemia (S)
docs.snippet: Pregnant women who show signs that their fetuses may have anemia, which in serious cases can require treatment even before the baby is born, have traditionally been advised to go undergo diagnostic procedures that involve physically piercing their...

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans are now living about three decades longer than they did at the start of the last century. But for far too many older Americans, the so-called Golden Years are tarnished by diseases that seriously undermine the quality of those extra decades -- diseases that with tools now at hand are usually preventable, postponable or detectable at a curable stage. Studies of centenarians, most of whom are healthy and independent, have revealed that it is possible not only to live long but well. Only about 30 percent of the differences in longevity among people can be traced to heredity. The rest can be attributed to how people live, especially their dietary, exercise and smoking habits and their use of protective medical services like vaccines and early detection tests.

headline.main: Adding Zest to the Golden Years, Simply

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on diseases that seriously undermine quality of life for older people and that are usually preventable, postponable or detectable at a curable stage; list of preventive measures that are partially or fully paid for by Medicare, but are often not used by elderly; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Americans are now living about three decades longer than they did at the start of the last century. But for far too many older Americans, the so-called Golden Years are tarnished by diseases that seriously undermine the quality of those extra decades...

docs.lead_paragraph: One of my most vivid childhood memories is a diet -- not for me but for my father. Year after year he would take it up, poring over a few sheets of typed instructions given to him by a family doctor, the ancient and rail thin Dr. M. D. Levin of Baltimore. Dr. Levin's diet was supposed to cure ulcers and prevent migraines, to give you energy and robust health. But, most important, to make you lose weight. It was a high-protein, low-carbohydrate diet, not so different from the diets sweeping the country today. You load up on meats and cut all the good stuff, like pasta and bread and dessert.

headline.main: True Secret Of Fad Diets: It's Calories

docs.abstract: Gina Kolata column debunks weight-loss claims made for high-protein, low-carb diets; says that there are no magical food to make you gain or lose weight and that all that mattters is calories, now matter what foods they come from (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There are many incompetent people in the world. Dr. David A. Dunning is haunted by the fear he might be one of them. Dr. Dunning, a professor of psychology at Cornell, worries about this because, according to his research, most incompetent people do not know that they are incompetent.

headline.main: Among the Inept, Researchers Discover, Ignorance Is Bliss

docs.abstract: Dr David A Dunning, professor of psychology at Cornell, finds that most incompetent people do not know that they are incompetent and are usually supremely confident of their abilities--more confident, in fact, than people who do things well; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A common virus related to those that cause meningitis and polio may play a role in the debilitating illness commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease. While scientists have long suspected that the enterovirus may play a role in the development of the disease, the new study appears to provide the strongest evidence to date to support this case.

headline.main: In Hot Pursuit of Lou Gehrig's Killer

docs.abstract: Enterovirus, common virus related to those that cause meningitis and polio, may play a role in the debilitating illness commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pleading doesn't usually work. Nor do threats of dire, if cosmetic, consequences. Even a good dollop of something yucky doesn't seem to do the trick. But could a simple elastic bandage be the cure for nighttime thumb- and digit-sucking in children? An article in a recent issue of Pediatric Dentistry says that may well be the case.
docs.abstract: New study shows that simple elastic bandage could be cure for nighttime thumb- and digit-sucking in children, which, if it persists, can cause embarrassment and dental problems; drawing (S)
